results.title: Glenn Gould: two portraits of the celebrated artist
results.creator_credit: Wolf Koenig, Roman Kroitor, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A fascinating two part documentary which follows the young and gifted musician Glenn Gould from his home town near Lake Simcoe, Canada to a recording studio in New York. Includes interviews with the artist and unique footage of him discussing composition with friend and fellow musician Franz Kraemar. Considered one of the greatest exponents of Bach, this portrait is an interesting view into the world of a sensitive creator and interpreter of music.

results.title: Glenn Gould on the record
results.creator_credit: Wolf Koenig, Roman Kroitor and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Follows celebrated Canadian concert pianist in New York kidding the taxi driver, bantering with sound engineers at Colombia Records, and then alone with the piano, fastidiously recording the Bach Italian concerto for a host of music lovers he will never see. Written by Stanley Jackson, photographed by Wolf Koenig.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Wolf Koenig, Roman Kroitor and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Glenn Gould off the record
results.creator_credit: Wolf Koenig, Roman Kroitor and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Celebrated Canadian concert pianist Glenn Gould, in the peaceful seclusion of his lakeside cottage. A view of Gould previously known only to intimates; to the collies pacing him through the woods, the fishermen resting their oars to catch the sublime echo of Bach from the distant shore, and the fellow musicians like Franz Kreemer, to whom Gould talks of composition. Edited by James Beveridge. Camera by Wolf Koenig.

results.title: Glengarry Glen Ross
results.creator_credit: James Foley, Stanley R Zupnik, Jerry Tokofsky and Zupnik Enterprises
results.brief_description: In response to poor sales figures, a consulting salesman offers an incentive to a group of Chicago real-estate salesmen. The agent with the most sales at the end of the month wins a Cadillac, second prize is a set of steak knives, third prize is the sack!! Now more than ever the pressure is on to perform and the salesmen are desperate to do anything to hold on to their jobs… even robbery, extortion and embezzlement. David Mamet’s moving screenplay (based on his play) focuses on the dilemmas of the various salesmen desperate to keep their jobs who sustain themselves by reliving past glories. Stars an ensemble of fine actors including Al Pacino, Jack Lemmon, Alec Baldwin, Ed Harris and Alan Arkin.

results.title: Glen or Glenda
results.creator_credit: Edward Wood Jr, George Weiss, Screen Classics and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: In his heart-felt cinematic debut, Edward D. Wood, Jr. himself stars under the pseudonym Daniel Davis as a young man with a dilemma: should he tell his lovely young fiancee (played by real-life girlfriend Dolores Fuller) about his burning desire to cross-dress? She has begun to notice articles of clothing missing from her closet; the suspense builds, what should he do? Bela Lugosi plays the omniscient narrator; note his conviction as he “pulls the strings.” Amidst this unintentionally hilarious mish-mash of melodrama, social commentary and inexplicable stock footage, there is something for every taste: countless cross dressers, hallucinatory dream sequences, sex-change surgeries, spirited cat fights, borderline-pornographic simulated sex scenes, poetic monologues, a haunted house, and a stampede of wild buffalo. Released under various titles across the country — I Lived Two Lives, I Changed My Sex — this fiasco bombed across the board but managed to gain Wood enough notoriety in the “B”-movie world to launch a career that is today the stuff of legend. Hailed by most critics as the worst film of all time. Includes Bela Lugosi film promos: ‘Dracula’, ‘The Body Snatchers’, ‘Frankenstein meets the Wolfman’, ‘Plan 9 from Outer Space’ & ‘Abbott and Costello meet Frankenstein’.

results.title: Glazing
results.creator_credit: Richard Philps and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids
results.brief_description: The film deals entirely with glazing, demonstrating the techniques of glazing mugs, jugs, dishes and bowls, and the decorative effects that can be obtained. The use of transparent glaze is explained and in addition, extra glazing effects such as matt stoneware glaze and oxides on rough and smooth surfaces are demonstrated.

results.title: Glaucoma: Sneak thief of sight
results.brief_description: Discusses the causes, diagnosis, and control of glaucoma, stressing the urgency of early detection of the disease in order to prevent blindness. Depicts various forms of the disease and includes artwork sequences to explain the anatomy of the eye.
results.description: Discusses the causes, diagnosis, and control of glaucoma, stressing the urgency of early detection of the disease in order to prevent blindness. Depicts various forms of the disease and includes artwork sequences to explain the anatomy of the eye.

results.title: Glasshouse soils
results.creator_credit: Mary Beales, Jack Chambers and Central Office of Inofrmation Film
results.brief_description: Shows the need for regular sterilisation of glasshouse soils if plant diseases are to be avoided. The methods used at the Cheshunt Experimental and Research Station, England, are described.

results.title: Glasses for Susan a new day
results.brief_description: In an effort to emphasize the importance of good vision in many areas of daily life, this film follows the course of a young schoolgirl as she blunders her way along, ignorant that she has poor eyesight. With the help of an alert teacher she becomes aware of her problem and in the process of acquiring a pair of new glasses she gains a new visual perspective of the world.

results.title: Glasses
results.creator_credit: Brian Duchscherer, Marcy Page and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Young Milo is a sensitive boy who like most other children just wants to be accepted at school. Above all, he yearns for the freedom and independence enjoyed by his comic book hero, Captain Cosmo, and resents his mother’s constant care and attention especially the plain, generic lunchbox she gives him instead of a Captain Cosmo one that all his other classmates own. What really holds Milo back is his poor eyesight: the world is fuzzy and this makes things difficult. He is rejected by the soccer team because he cannot score properly and ridiculed in class because he constantly misreads the numbers on the cards which his teacher puts before him. However, a trip to the optometrist and a pair of glasses improves things. But not totally. Though Milo can now read the numbers correctly in class, he still encounters trouble at soccer and bullying from his classmates. When things are at rock bottom however, Milo learns what is important and has his first experience of accepting life for what it is. Brian Duchscherer’s puppet animation is a joy to watch and brings to vivid life recognisable characters and important themes.
